did.abstract: The Society of American Archivists (SAA) is the oldest and largest national professional association of archivists in North America. The collection contains materials from the organization of the SAA in 1936 to present day. The main record groups document the activities of the SAA officers; councilors; executive directors; the editorship of The American Archivist; and SAA committees, roundtables, sections, and task forces.

bioghist.p: The 1930s saw an unprecedented amount of archival activity in the United States: the establishment of the National Archives (1934); the organization of the Historical Records Survey and the Survey of Federal Archives (1936-1937); and the establishment of the Society of American Archivists (1936), the first professional organization of archivists in North America.

At the December 1935 meeting of the American Historical Association (AHA), a conference of fifty-one participants met to discuss the possibility of forming a national professional organization of archivists. Conference attendees unanimously agreed to establish such an organization at the next AHA meeting and charged a steering committee to draft a constitution. The "Committee of Ten on the Organization of Archivists" was chaired by Solon J. Buck and included Ruth Blair, Theodore C. Blegen, Alexander C. Flick, Curtis W. Garrison, R.B. Haselden, Waldo G. Leland, A.R. Newsome, Margaret Cross Norton, and James A. Robertson.

Attendees of the December 1936 AHA meeting, held in Providence, Rhode Island, approved the draft constitution, and elected officers and a five-member Council. Newsome served as SAA's first president, Norton as vice president, Philip C. Brooks as secretary, and Julian P. Boyd as treasurer. Council members included Blair, Blegen, Buck, Victor H. Paltsists, and Lawrence C. Wroth. The constitution provided for the establishment of twelve committees on a wide variety of topics, including international archival affairs, maps and charts, membership, public relations, reduction of archival material, and terminology. The number of committees was more than the active membership could sustain, and many were inactive for a number of years or eventually allowed to lapse. At this time, the constitution restricted membership to "those who are or have been engaged in the custody or administration of archives or historical manuscripts or who, because of a special experience or other qualifications, are recognized as competent in archival economy." A pro forma election of every applicant for membership was also required.

The first annual meeting was held in Washington, D.C. in June 1937. By this time, 226 individuals had been elected to the Society, one third of whom were women. SAA was largely an east coast organization, with a great number of its leaders coming from the National Archives. It was incorporated in Washington, D.C. in 1945.

SAA's first publication was a 104-page volume of the proceedings of the 1936 organizing meeting and the 1937 annual meeting. The first issue of The American Archivist followed in January 1938. Under the editorship of Theodore C. Pease, professor of history at the University of Chicago, the journal focused more on the use of archives in writing history than on archival administration. This emphasis upset members who felt that The American Archivist should be a trade publication, not a scholarly journal. Tensions over this and other matters led to Pease's resignation in 1945 and the appointment of Margaret Cross Norton, state archivist of Illinois.

During WWII, SAA concentrated on issues relating to the preservation of records not only for historians, but also for the war effort. Several committees reflected these new interests. They included the Collection and Preservation of Materials for the History of Emergencies Committee, the History and Organization of Governmental Emergency Agencies Committee, the Emergency Transfer and Storage of Archives Committee, and the Protection of Archives Against the Hazards of War Committee. At the end of the war, SAA supported the formation of the International Council on Archives (ICA) as a means of rebuilding ties among archivists around the world.

In order to legitimize itself as the national association of archivists, SAA forged relations with other national organizations to discuss issues of mutual concern. A joint committee with the American Association for State and Local History (AASLH) on historical manuscripts eventually led to the National Union Catalog of Manuscript Collections. Meetings with the National Association of State Librarians later led to the formation of the Joint ALA-SAA Committee on Library-Archives Relationships. SAA's status as a national organization was signaled in other ways, as well. In 1947, the annual meeting was held west of the Mississippi for the first time, in Glenwood Springs and Denver, Colorado.

By 1957, membership grew to 648 individual members (as separate from institutional members or subscribers). It reflected an increasingly diverse geographical distribution, with a greater number of members coming from regions other than the east coast. To encourage membership growth, Council passed an amendment in 1955 to accept individuals who are or have been "engaged in the custody, study, teaching, or control of records, archives, or private papers," and those "who wish to support the objectives of the Society." The requirement of a pro forma election of every applicant was also discontinued.

During the mid-1950s, SAA took steps to honor members who made significant contributions to the theory and practice of archival administration, and who thereby encouraged others to improve the standards of the profession. In 1956, the Professional Standards and Training Committee recommended that Council establish "a special class of members of the Society known as Fellows of the Society of American Archivists." A constitutional amendment to that effect was approved at the 1957 annual meeting.

SAA honors the contributions of individuals and archival agencies in other ways. In 1963, the State and Local Records Committee recommended the establishment of the Distinguished Service Award to recognize a North American archival institution, organization, education program, or nonprofit or governmental organization that has given outstanding service to its public and has made an exemplary contribution to the archival profession. Other awards have included the Gondos Memorial Award; the Waldo Gifford Leland Prize; and the Philip M. Hamer Award.

Committees played an important role in advancing SAA's mission, but by the late 1960s it was apparent that various factors hobbled the efforts of committees to communicate and work effectively. Committee members were scattered across the country, conducted most of their work by correspondence and telephone, and usually met only at annual meetings. In his 1968-1969 report on the committee system, Secretary Gerald F. Ham explained that many committees had vaguely defined areas of responsibility or no longer met the needs of the membership. In an attempt to remedy the situation, Council approved a revised structure of standing and ad hoc committees at the December 1969 meeting. In this major reorganization, several committees were abolished, others were consolidated, and the functions and responsibilities of still others were broadened. Additionally, new committees on machine-readable records; oral history; urban and industrial archives; and reference, access, and photo-duplication policies were created. These changes made the committee structure more responsive to the needs of the membership, but they did not help committees work more effectively. The problem of ineffective and inactive committees would be addressed in different ways in the following years.

In 1970, President Philip P. Mason appointed the Committee for the 1970s to "analyze the present structure of the Society, its program and objectives, its relationship with other professional organizations, and most importantly, its needs during the coming decade." Recommendations made by the committee had a decisive impact on the future direction of SAA. The committee focused on eight areas: SAA's organizational structure and operations; relations with other professional groups and organizations; the committee system; SAA publications; membership relations and development; education and training; annual meetings, conferences, and symposia; and finances. An interim report of the committee was distributed to the membership in September 1971, and the final report published in the April 1972 issue of the American Archivist.

Following the recommendation of the Committee for the 1970s, the membership approved an amendment that allowed the elected secretary to be replaced by an executive director. Secretary Robert M. Warner had already served a year of his term when he agreed in 1972 to serve an additional year as the appointed (but unpaid) executive director. In 1973, Warner resigned, and Judith A. Koucky served as acting secretary until a replacement could be found. Ann Morgan Campbell was hired in July 1974 as the first paid executive director, and offices were established on the Chicago Circle campus of the University of Illinois.

Following other recommendations of the Committee for the 1970s, SAA began publication of the SAA Newsletter in 1973 (renamed Archival Outlook in 1993), and established an executive committee to operate for Council between meetings.

In October 1978, Council made another effort to remedy the problem of inefficient and inactive committees. Acting on the recommendation of the Committee on Committees, Council adopted a three-part organization of committees, task forces, and professional affinity groups (PAGs). Standing and joint committees were assigned the function of ensuring the regular conduct of SAA's affairs or representing SAA on inter-association committees with affiliated professions. Task forces were created to address specific issues or questions facing SAA. PAGs were established on the basis of institutional affiliation and/or functional responsibility, and provided members with an opportunity to meet and work with others of similar backgrounds and professional interests. PAGs convened for the first time at the September 1979 annual meeting. All PAGs became known as sections at the end of the annual business meeting in 1983. A fourth unit of SAA, roundtables, was added in January 1985. Like sections, roundtables provided members with similar professional interests the opportunity to meet and work together. Unlike sections, they required a minimum of only twenty members.

arrangement.p: This collection was received in, and is organized in, multiple parts. Additional materials have not been physically or intellectually arranged and interfiled, and researchers may need to consult more than one part of the collection to locate similar materials.

While on deposit at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, the collection was assigned the record group number 200. When it was donated to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, the collection was assigned a new number (UWM Manuscript Collection 172), but the original record group number was retained on boxes and folders and remains important for paging materials.

otherfindaid.p: A spreadsheet with file-level information on the electronic records in series 1.27, 8.1, 8.3, 8.4, 9.1, 9.2, and 9.3 is available in the Archives department. These spreadsheets are organized by accession, and some crosswalking may be necessary to find metadata for particular files. Additional technical metadata is available; see an archivist for details.

phystech.p: As of January 25, 2017, all electronic files were accessible on an Intel Core i5-4570 CPU (3.20 GHz, 4 GB RAM) running Windows 7 Enterprise with service pack 1. Software used to access the files includes Windows Picture and Fax Viewer, Adobe Reader, Windows Notepad, LibreOffice, and Windows Media Player.
The collection includes records in the following file formats:

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material in the UWM Libraries

accessrestrict.p: Electronic records must be accessed in the Archives reading room, and researchers must use access copies. See an archivist for more information.

Other access restrictions are described in the contents list. Unless noted otherwise, there are no access restrictions on the materials, and the collection is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39). SAA retains its copyright in this collection.

custodhist.p: Provision for long-term preservation of SAA's records was originally made by section 21 of its constitution (1936), which reads:

blockquote.p: The minute books, correspondence, and other records of the Society and its committees shall be preserved by the officers and chairmen of the committees and shall be promptly turned over by them to the secretary when their terms expire. Records that have ceased to be of use in conducting the current affairs of the Society may, by direction of the council, be turned over to a depository selected by it for permanent preservation.

custodhist.p: Until Council designated a depository in the 1960s, the records migrated with each new secretary, who was expected to maintain control over them. This arrangement was manageable when the records amounted to only a few feet, but it proved impractical as their bulk increased. Complicating the situation was the fact that officers and committee chairs were slow in turning over non-active records. When records were passed to the secretary, they often lacked any order. In his report at the annual meeting, Secretary Henry Browne remarked the "exciting arrival" of several boxes from his predecessor, archivist at the Ford Motor Company. The boxes "looked like a do-it-yourself kit for maintaining a Thunderbird," he joked. "They proved to be the archives of the Society."

Dolores Renze, Colorado State Archivist, was the first secretary to make preservation and processing of the records an ongoing priority. During her term, the archives grew substantially. However, like Browne before her, Renze complained that many past presidents and committee chairs declined to turn over their files, and those who did were "most dilatory in applying [to their own records] the principles of preservation and arrangement which they propound" as professional archivists.

On October 2, 1963, Council resolved that "the archives of the Society be deposited in the official custody of an appointed archivist" and that they "be processed, housed, and serviced in conformance with sound archival principles." Upon completing her term as secretary, Renze was appointed as the first SAA archivist, and the Colorado State Archives designated as the official depository.

On December 30, 1969, Council determined that it was again desirable to place the records under the care of the secretary. Accordingly, President Kahn informed Renze that the records were to be placed in the custody of Gerald F. Ham and placed on deposit at the State Historical Society of Wisconsin (now Wisconsin Historical Society) in Madison. Almost two years later, Ham reported that the records had yet to be sent, and Council made arrangements to assist Renze in delivering the records.

During a January 1976 Council meeting, it was reported that the "greatest volume of the Society's archives" were on deposit at the State Historical Society of Wisconsin, although "there were additional segments of the records in the custody of several former SAA officers." Councilor J. Frank Cook chaired a committee to collect records of SAA's first forty years, but it yielded few results. During this time, Council began emphasizing the importance of designating a permanent depository, believing that such action would encourage officers and chairs to transfer inactive records.

On October 2, 1978, Council accepted the offer of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Division of Archives, to serve as the permanent depository of SAA's archives and appointed Cook as SAA archivist. Cook and the UW-Madison staff provided access to and preserved the records until Cook's retirement in September 2000. At that time, Council donated its archives to the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) Libraries and named the head of its Archives Department as SAA archivist. The records arrived at Milwaukee in April 2001. Section 7 of the SAA Constitution currently provides for the placement and preservation of the SAA archives.

acqinfo.p: The Society of American Archivists made the initial donation of its records in April 2001 (accession 2001-003). Detailed information about subsequent accessions is available upon request.

processinfo.p: Detailed information about processing is available upon request.

processinfo.head: Preservation Information
processinfo.p: During processing, digital audio files in .mp3 format originally received on CDs were copied to network storage and now serve as preservation master and access copies. The original CDs were discarded.

During processing of administrative files from the SAA Oral History project, files were migrated to preservation formats using the National Archives of Australia's XENA digital preservation software. Files in their original formats will serve as the access copies.

physdesc.extent: 271.9 cubic ft. (385 boxes, including 16 audio cassettes and 33 videocassettes)

scopecontent.p: This subgroup contains presidents' correspondence with other SAA officers and The American Archivist editors. It also includes files relating to annual meetings, Council, committees, sections, task forces, and joint meetings with other organizations.

arrangement.p: This subgroup is further arranged into sub-subgroups corresponding to the terms of SAA presidents and thereafter by series. Subgroups are numbered in the order in which they are processed, not according to the sequence of presidential terms. Since 1957, the vice president has served as president elect. Most subgroups accordingly include files from an individual's service in both roles.

scopecontent.p: This subgroup consists mainly of correspondence and subject files relating to Council and annual meetings. The bulk of the records dates from the 1970s.

arrangement.p: This subgroup is further arranged into groups corresponding to the terms of SAA vice presidents/president elects and thereafter by series. Since 1957, the vice president has served as president elect. In order to better reflect the continuity between an individual's service as president elect and president, the SAA archivist decided to arrange the records of presidents elect with their presidential papers. Accordingly, this subgroup was discontinued following SAA's donation of its archives to UW-Milwaukee in April 2001.

scopecontent.p: Records relate to the involvement of secretaries with The American Archivist, annual meetings, committees, Council, fellows, archival legislation, officers, and representatives. The records span 1936-1976, although the bulk dates from the 1960s and 1970s. In 1972, the executive director assumed the functions and responsibilities of the secretary.

arrangement.p: The first two sub-subgroups are collections of the records of Secretaries Phillip C. Brooks, 1936-1942; Lester J. Cappon, 1942-1950; Roger Thomas, 1950-1953; Henry E. Edmunds, 1953-1955; and Henry Browne, 1955-1956. Thereafter, sub-subgroups correspond to the terms of individual secretaries. These sub-subgroups are further arranged into series such as general files and committee files. In 1972, the executive director assumed the functions and responsibilities of the secretary. Accordingly, this subgroup has been discontinued.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: Council consists of the president, vice-president, treasurer and nine councilors elected at-large by the Society. The files in this record subgroup were created by persons serving as elected Council members. Records vary among Council members, but generally include correspondence, meeting materials including referenced documents and minutes, and records regarding Council's interaction with SAA committees, sections, and roundtables. The majority of records in this subgroup--those processed after SAA's donation of its archives to UW-Milwaukee in April 2001--include only those compiled and created by members during their official terms of Council service.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: This series also includes official pronouncements of the organization approved by the Council and promulgated publicly. SAA Council meeting agendas and minutes, including reports from appointed committees, component groups, working groups, and individual officers. Various iterations of SAA's strategic plan, including Vision and Mission Statements, Core Organizational Values, Goals, Strategies, and Key Performance Indicators. SAA's Governance Manual that describes the organization's structure, officers, component groups, awards program, and student chapters. And leadership resources and policies developed by SAA to assist leaders of sections, roundtables, committees, and other component groups with leadership policies and best practices.

arrangement.p: This group brings together small collections of multiple Council members.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: The executive director manages the programs, activities, and staff of SAA. S/he keeps the minutes of SAA and Council, prepares and mails notices, presents an annual report of the activities of SAA, manages the general operating budget, and performs such other duties as may be directed by Council. Notable topics in this record subgroup include the annual meeting; the American Archivist editorial office; regional and international archival organizations; SAA units, staff, Council and executive committee; professional organizations affiliated with SAA; and grants and special projects.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: Includes official news items and press releases posted by the organization on its website and annual reports, containing information on activities, professional development offerings, financial status, and membership trends.

arrangement.p: This record subgroup was originally arranged into groups corresponding to the terms of SAA executive directors. These groups were further arranged into series such as committee files, general files, and general correspondence. Following SAA's donation of its archives to UW-Milwaukee in April 2001, arrangement based upon individual executive director was discontinued. Additions to this subgroup are now arranged into series of administrative files, general correspondence, executive committee correspondence, Council files, and SAA units files. Researchers are advised to consult files in each arrangement scheme for full documentation of an executive director.

scopecontent.p: This record subgroup consists of records relating to the production of the American Archivist, SAA's journal. The editor's records date from 1936 and anticipate the publication of the first issue in January 1938. Records of the book reviews editor date from 1942, although the American Archivist has devoted sections to announce and review publications relevant to archives administration since its first issue. Records of the advertising editor date from 1948, when the American Archivist first included advertisements among its pages. The bulk of the record subgroup consists of documentation pertaining to the editorial process and includes manuscripts submitted for publication, evaluations of manuscripts by the editorial board, the editors' summaries of board evaluations, editor-author correspondence.

arrangement.p:
This record subgroup was originally arranged into groups that largely corresponded to the terms of American Archivist editors. Sub-subgroups 6, 7, and 13 collectively group the records of book review editors, advertising editors, and special issues editors, respectively. Sub-subgroup 12 collectively groups articles submitted for publication from 1971 to 1984.
Following SAA's donation of its archives to UW-Milwaukee in April 2001, the SAA archivist discontinued arrangement of this record subgroup by individual and collective editors. Additions to this group are now arranged as four major series: administrative files, correspondence, articles accepted, and articles rejected.

accessrestrict.p: Identity-specific evaluation records are restricted for forty years after the date of the document or following the death of the evaluator, whichever occurs first. Unpublished manuscripts are restricted for forty years.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: This subgroup includes records of standing and ad hoc committees. Records survive for many of the original twelve committees established at the organizing meeting. This part of the collection also provides extensive background information about two significant revisions in SAA's committee structure. In 1969, Council approved a revised structure of standing and ad hoc committees as set up by the president in consultation with other officers. This revised system remained in place until 1978, when Council adopted a three-part organization of committees, task forces, and professional affinity groups (PAGs). Typically, committee files may include correspondence, minutes, and reports. Researchers should also consult the records of the secretary and executive director, who receive committee reports.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: This includes records of Council-appointed and/or elected committees, including their charge, reports, and meeting minutes. Also included are links to awards and other forms of recognition conferred by SAA as of August 2014.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: Council created Professional Affinity Groups (PAGs) in 1978 to provide members with an opportunity to meet and work with others of similar backgrounds and professional interests. All PAGs were renamed as sections at the end of the annual business meeting in 1983. Files typically contain correspondence, meeting minutes, reports, newsletters and other publications relating to the work of the section. Researchers should also consult the records of the executive director, who receives section reports.

From 2009 to 2012, the Oral History Section created a series of interviews as part of the SAA 75th Anniversary Oral History Project. These interviews, along with previous oral histories, can be found under the Oral History Section records.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: Records of Sections as of August 2016.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence of the meeting planner and the Program and Local Arrangements Committees, attendee surveys, and annual meeting programs. The programs are the richest source of information in this group; they include names of presenters, titles of papers, and, from 1972 forward, session abstracts. Documentation of the annual meetings is uneven. The bulk of the records date from 1937 to 1943, 1958 to 1963, and 1987 to the present.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: Includes links to archived microsites of SAA's Annual Meeting, including original meeting pages, preliminary programs (PDFs), and selected photographs captured by SAA. Session Recordings and presentation materials are generally not included.

scopecontent.head: Print Publications
scopecontent.p: This series consists of SAA monographs and serial publications. Monograph publications include titles from SAA's Basic Manual series, Archival Fundamentals series, and the Problems in Archives Kits series. Serial publications include the American Archivist, the Society's semiannual journal (1938-ongoing); Archival Outlook, its semimonthly newsletter (1973-ongoing); and member and repository directories. Although individually cataloged, these items are intellectually and physically arranged as part of SAA's archives.
This series also includes material that was related to the making of the Problems and Archives Kit Series.

scopecontent.head: SAA Web Collection
scopecontent.p: Includes the American Archivist, the American Archivist Online Supplement, and the American Archivist Reviews Portal, as well as other online publications.

bioghist.p:
SAA established the Basic Archival Conservation Program under an NEH grant in 1980. The initial program consisted of basic workshops, consultant visits, and the publication of a manual on conservation. SAA expanded the program with a second NEH grant for the period 1982-1984 and included new workshops on the Administration of Photographic Collections and an Introduction to Microforms. In 1984, Council created the position of education officer in the Chicago office. Timothy L. Ericson served as the first education officer from January through July 1984.
In June 1991, Council created the Education Office Advisory Board as a standing committee charged with advising on the offerings and administration of SAA's educational offerings. In its January 1997 report to Council, the Task Force on Organizational Effectiveness (TFOE) recommended that the Committee on Education and Professional Development assume the responsibilities of the advisory board and that the board itself be abolished. Council acted on the TFOE's recommendation during its January 1998 meeting.
In June 1999, Council established a Task Force on Continuing Education to evaluate and make recommendations regarding the future of the Society's education program and the position of an education officer. In its final report, presented May 2000, the task force recommended a major shift in the program, primarily supporting a move from offering basic workshops to offering online courses.

scopecontent.head: Physical Collection
scopecontent.p: This record subgroup includes records pertaining to SAA's Education Office and its precursor, the Basic Archival Conservation Program. It also includes the records of the Preservation Management Training Program, a National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH)-funded program that consisted of four series of workshops offered throughout the United States from 1992 to 1994, and the Native American Archives Project, an NEH-funded program that consisted of six regional tribal archives conferences, and production and distribution of a slide-tape program and publication, Native American Archives.

scopecontent.head: Web Collection
scopecontent.p: Includes the home page for the Digital Archives Specialist (DAS) program, established in 2011 to allow SAA to provide a multi-year coordinated program to address members needs for education and training in electronic records appraisal, capture, preservation, and access. The Continuing Professional Education Catalog contains links to workshops, webinars, and other professional development/continuing education opportunities offered or sponsored by SAA.
